Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[Xamarin.Android.Build.Tasks] Add support for Generated Resources via VSForMac" (#1327) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
Context https://bugzilla.xamarin.com/show_bug.cgi?id=5870

One of the issues with the current resource designer implementation
is that it is not in the intermediate directory. As a result it is
always causing problems for Source control systems.

Additionally normal .net apps create generated files in the
intermediate directory and make use of the a target and make use
of "build time code generation" [1] by making use of the Generator
metadata in MSBuild. Visual studio already has support for this
however VSForMac did not.

The issue with VSForMac is now being solved. With this commit
we will introduce a new target UpdateGeneratedFiles which can be
used by both VS and XS to generate the Resource.Designer.xx file
in the intermediate directory.

All of this is current protected by the AndroidUseIntermediateDesignerFile
property which defaults to false.

[1] https://mhut.ch/journal/2015/06/30/build_time_code_generation_msbuild

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed pull request "Bump to xamarin-android-api-compatibility/master/9cfa6cc9" (#1078) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
We found that xamarin-android-api-compatibility wasn't *actually*
performing the inter-API-level checks, meaning an important API
compatibility check wasn't being performed.

Bump to xamarin-android-api-compatibility/9cfa6cc9 so that
inter-API-level checks are properly performed.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Bump to xamarin-android-api-compatibility/master/2c689ef2" (#1328) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
Fixes: https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/issues/1089

We found that xamarin-android-api-compatibility wasn't *actually*
performing the inter-API-level checks, meaning an important API
compatibility check wasn't being performed.

Bump to xamarin-android-api-compatibility/2c689ef2 so that
inter-API-level checks are properly performed.

Additionally, set `$(HTML_OUTPUT_DIR)` so that `mono-api-html` output
files are written into `bin/Build$(CONFIGURATION)/compatibility`.
This will (hopefully) allow us to use the Jenkins
**Publish HTML reports** Post-build Action to nicely display API
compatibility breakage, without requiring that we read the actual
build log output.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[monodroid] Use .aot extension for default aot profiler output" (#1254) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
When the profiler output filename is not set, we set our own, which is
written in the `.__override__` directory. It is now set to
`profile.aot` for the `aot` profiler and `.mlpd` for the `log`
profiler.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[Xamarin.Android.Build.Tasks] Add support for Generated Resources via VSForMac (#643)" (#1326) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
Context https://bugzilla.xamarin.com/show_bug.cgi?id=5870

One of the issues with the current resource designer implementation
is that it is not in the intermediate directory. As a result it is
always causing problems for Source control systems.

Additionally normal .net apps create generated files in the
intermediate directory and make use of the a target and make use
of "build time code generation" [1] by making use if the Generator
metadata in MSBuild. Visual studio already has support for this
however VisualStudioForMac did not.

The issue with VisualStudioForMac is now being solved. With this commit
we will introduce a new target UpdateGeneratedFiles which can be
used by both VS and XS to generate the Resource.Designer.xx file
in the intermediate directory.

All of this is current protected by the AndroidUseIntermediateDesignerFile
property which defaults to false.

[1] https://mhut.ch/journal/2015/06/30/build_time_code_generation_msbuild

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[Xamarin.Android.Build.Tasks] Update `CalculateProjectDependencies` to match new spec." (#1323) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
The path separator for the android manifest change from
a `;` to a '/'. This commit updates the `CalculateProjectDependencies`
task to use the new format. It also updates the tests.

The current manifest [1] has been updated to [2]. It seems the general reasoning was to make the way the components are queried via the Sdk Manager and the MsBuild tasks consistent. It also makes the output of the `CalculateProjectDependencies` more `msbuild` friendly. 

The new manifest [2] now has a `filesystem-path` in addition to the `path`

`path="build-tools;27.0.3" filesystem-path="build-tools/27.0.3"`

Note that the `filesystem-path` includes `/` rather than `;`. Prior to this change the `InstallAndroidDependencies` needed to fix up the output of `CalculateProjectDependencies` to correctly query the SDK Manager for installed components. With this change both the `InstallAndroidDependencies` Task and the Command line tool can consume the output of `CalculateProjectDependencies` without any changes. The AndroidDependency will now have items
such as

`platforms/android-21`
`build-tools/27.0.3`
`ndk-bundle`

Version numbers are still provided as metadata as per the spec [3].

[1] https://xamarin.azureedge.net/Installer/xamarin-android-sdk.xml
[2] [xamarin-android-sdk.xml](https://gist.github.com/dellis1972/08ba76cc19cdce3dec89c68684664299)
[3] [Spec](https://microsoft-my.sharepoint.com/:w:/r/personal/mhutch_microsoft_com/_layouts/15/WopiFrame.aspx?sourcedoc=%7B0436dd38-c9ff-4cf2-b33c-ee4515b68546%7D&action=edit&wdPid=64869a58)

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Bump to mono/2017-12/de4729fa" (#1325) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Can't Intercept Software Back Button" (#1944) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
### Description
Software back button doesn't use the same code paths as the hardware back button. This leads to unexpected behaviour on Android (and from what I've read, iOS).

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Override the "OnBackButtonPressed()" method on MasterDetailPage.
2. Run application on Android and navigate to a detail page in the MasterDetailPage.
3. Press the "Back" arrow on the command bar.

### Expected Behavior
The "OnBackButtonPressed()" method should be invoked, same as when the hardware "back" button is pressed.

### Actual Behavior
The method is not invoked.

### Basic Information

- Version with issue:
- Last known good version: Unknown
- IDE: Visual Studio 2017
- Platform Target Frameworks:
  - Android: 8.0 Oreo
  - UWP: UWP 16299 (Works fine!)
- Android Support Library Version: v7/v4
- Nuget Packages:

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Slider crashes when Minimum value greater than zero and set before Max value in XAML" (#1943) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues

### Description
Migrating https://bugzilla.xamarin.com/show_bug.cgi?id=43435 here

The difference between the working and crashing versions is the order of the Minimum and Maximum properties in the XAML. Note that if Minimum is set to zero, the order is no longer an issue.

### Steps to Reproduce

Run app, note that it works fine
Uncomment line #8 in MainPage.xaml
Run app, note it crashes with "System.ArgumentException: Value was an invalid value for Minimum"

### Expected Behavior
App does not crash

### Actual Behavior
App crashes

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: 2.5.0.280555
- Last known good version: N/A
- IDE: VS2017
- Platform Target Frameworks: <!-- All that apply -->
  - iOS:  yes
  - Android: yes
  - UWP:  not tested
- Android Support Library Version: 25
- Nuget Packages: just forms
- Affected Devices: tested on Nexus 5x running Android 7, and iPhone 5s simulator running iOS 9.3

### Reproduction Link
https://www.dropbox.com/s/qdweqnvh1hsj4wh/slidercrashsample.zip?dl=0
